Award.AwardTitle: Scandium Nitride Crystal Growth and Characterization
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Description: Scandium nitride is a semiconductor, which like silicon can be used for electronic devices, but has rarely been studied. This project focuses on making single crystals of scandium nitride that are free of defects and with low concentrations of impurities, as this is necessary for studying intrinsic properties of this material and determining its potential for future device applications such as light emitting diodes and high-temperature electronics. Scandium nitride crystals have been difficult to produce because of its very high melting temperatures. The crystal growth method used in this research, physical vapor transport, produces larger, better quality scandium nitride crystals than previously employed methods. Graduate students supported by this project are receiving hands-on research training while making new scientific discoveries and developing new technologies. This project also introduces young women (12 to 14 years old) to the science and technology of crystal growth and semiconductors, through the K-State Girls Researching Our World summer workshops.

Technical Description: Single crystals of scandium nitride (ScN) with no or significantly fewer defects are grown to explore the intrinsic electrical properties of this semiconductor. To achieve this goal, the specific activities of the research are as follows. First, the process of crystal growth by physical vapor transport is optimized by adjusting the furnace temperature, pressure, and configuration to produce material with low defect densities and low impurity concentrations. These experiments are guided by thermodynamic and transport phenomena modeling. Second, the electrical properties of ScN are measured and correlated with the temperature and impurity concentrations, to reveal its electrical conduction energetics. Specifically, the electron mobility and charge carrier concentrations are determined by temperature-dependent Hall effect measurements and are correlated with the crystal defect densities (determined by defect sensitive etching), deviations from stoichiometry, and impurity concentrations (measured by secondary ion mass spectrometry). Third, selected impurities are intentionally added to scandium nitride to determine how they change its electrical properties. Differences in the properties caused by the crystal orientation and polarity (nitrogen or scandium) are investigated. By correlating these measurements with the process conditions, methods of controlling ScN's electrical properties are under development. This study provides valuable intrinsic electrical properties of ScN for future device explorations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The properties of two new semiconductors, scandium nitride and erbium nitride, were thoroughly characterized. The information collected is important for designing electronic and optoelectronic devices such as transistors and light emitting diodes that incorporate these materials. To establish their best possible properties, a new technique, the physical vapor transport method, was developed to produce single crystals with low defect densities and impurity concentrations.  Structural defects and high impurity concentrations degrade the properties of a semiconductor, which in turn reduce device performance and efficiency. 

Several steps were taken to produce high quality crystals. The process employed very high temperatures, between 1750 and 2150 Celsius.  The growth rate increases with temperature, thus making it possible to produce thick layers, greater than 1 mm (Figure 1), in a reasonable amount of time.  These crystals were a thousand times thicker than most prior studies, which significantly reduced the defect densities in the crystals. Growth was initiated on single crystals of tungsten, to control the orientation of the growing crystals. This supported single crystal growth, and eliminated crystal grain boundaries. Furthermore, the growth chamber was designed to suppress spurious, random crystal growth, by adjusting the temperature distribution in the furnace, by attaching a cooling fin to the seed crystals.

The resulting electrical and thermal properties of the crystals were indicative of low defect densities. For example, the scandium nitride had a room temperature free electron carrier concentration of 2.0 x 1021 cm-3, and an electron mobility of 75 cm2/V-s, the latter more than twice that of most thin layers.  Its room temperature thermal conductivity was k = 54 W m-1 K-1, more than three times higher than values previously reported for films that were less than 1 micron thick.  Other properties were similarly improved. 

Thus, this project was able to establish the basic properties of these two semiconductors, and demonstrate that physical vapor transport is an excellent method to produce these materials. This work can be the basis for developing these materials for devices, and/or employing this same method to produce a wide variety of refractory metal nitrides, to discover their basic properties and explore their potential device applications.

This project also included outreach via the Kansas State University Girls Researching our World (GROW) program.  Workshops for girls ages 11 to 13 were held on crystal growth, their properties, and applications (Figure 2). The girls were introduced to the concepts of symmetry, grew crystals from simple inorganic salt solutions, and observed crystals found in light emitting diodes under a microscope. These workshops were designed to be fun and intellectually intriguing, to encourage the students to consider choosing to study science, technology and engineering in their education.
